html:
Use pstree command to see your running processes as tree in #linux pic.twitter.com/qExhS0BaYx

— Vishnu Bharathi (@scriptnull) January 7, 2018

Use file utility to know about your files on #linux

$ file ~/twitter.txt
twitter.txt: ASCII text

$ file /dev
/dev: directory

$ file /sbin/init
/sbin/init: symbolic link to /lib/systemd/systemd

— Vishnu Bharathi (@scriptnull) December 31, 2017

Use man to learn about your favorite system call on #linux

$ man 2 system-call-name

— Vishnu Bharathi (@scriptnull) December 31, 2017

open
read
write
close
lseek
fcntl
dup
dup2
dup3
pread
pwrite
readv
writev
preadv
pwritev
truncate
ftruncate

so much fun! so much wow! #linux

— Vishnu Bharathi (@scriptnull) December 31, 2017

File descriptor 0 is stdin - standard input.
File descriptor 1 is stdout - standard output.
File descriptor 2 is stderr - standard error.#linux

— Vishnu Bharathi (@scriptnull) December 30, 2017

So, I did this as mentioned. In case if you are wondering how to do it. Here it is

$ echo "hello" > target.txt
$ ln -s target.txt symlink
$ cat symlink
$ rm target.txt
$ cat symlink # tada ðŸŽ‰ you have a dangling link https://t.co/xKzRDuOZDd

— Vishnu Bharathi (@scriptnull) December 17, 2017

A process can exit due to two reasons

1) It calls _exit() system call and tells the kernel to terminate itself
2) By delivery of a signal

(( Planning to write down a program to demonstrate this and learn more about this ))#Linux

— Vishnu Bharathi (@scriptnull) December 16, 2017

A process has a Process Identifier (PID) and a Parent Process Identifier (PPID)

$ ps -lax#Linux

— Vishnu Bharathi (@scriptnull) December 16, 2017

Me : my process is creating a new process

Kernel : No, my boy! Your process just requested me to create a new process for you. Here it is, go ahead and open my gift.

Me : can you also gift me a Linux T-shirt?

Kernel : Hell no! Go online and order it#linux

— Vishnu Bharathi (@scriptnull) December 15, 2017

All users in #linux have a User ID (UID)

Know your user id by checking /etc/passwd file.

User ID of root is always 0 (zero)

— Vishnu Bharathi (@scriptnull) December 15, 2017

Portable filename character set is [-._a-zA-Z0-9]

Try to use these 65 characters while naming your files on #linux

— Vishnu Bharathi (@scriptnull) December 13, 2017

Every directory contains at least two links

. (dot) - link to the directory itself
.. (dot dot) - link to the parent directory

Every directory except root directory has a parent. So .. (dot dot) in root directory refers to itself.#Linux

— Vishnu Bharathi (@scriptnull) December 13, 2017

A file can be one of the following types in #Linux

1) regular/plain file
2) device
3) pipe
4) socket
5) directory
6) symbolic link

Speaking of which I remember fs.Stats providing synchronous functions for checking the type of a file in node.js pic.twitter.com/2JZJURkGpG

— Vishnu Bharathi (@scriptnull) December 13, 2017

Find all the users on a #linux machine using
$ sudo cat /etc/passwd

Find all the groups on a #linux machine using
$ sudo cat /etc/group

— Vishnu Bharathi (@scriptnull) December 13, 2017
